âœ¨How To Make SOURDOUGH Irish Soda Breadâœ¨

This is a really fun dough to â€œkneadâ€ and shape. So soft. So squishy. You can make it with sourdough discard or active starter- itâ€™s up to you. Youâ€™ll need about 1 cup. Once baked, the taste is slightly sweet, not too dense, and perfect with a pat of salted butter. This recipe is adapted from the lovable @inagarten. Iâ€™ve been making her famous soda bread since 2012! ğŸ’š

Ingredients:

375 g (3 cups) all purpose flour
50 g (4 tbsp) granulated sugar
5 g (1 tsp) baking soda
7 g (1 1/2 tsp) fine sea salt
60 g (4 tbsp) unsalted butter, cold, cut into small cubes
1 large egg
170 g (appx. 3/4 cup) buttermilk
200 g (appx. 1 cup) sourdough starter discard or active sourdough starter
150 g (1 cup) raisins

Short hand method:
Preheat oven to 375 F/190 C. 
In a stand mixer: combine dry ingredients. Add butter cubes, one at a time. Add wet ingredients. Mix to to incorporate. Knead dough on a lightly floured surface, just to bring it together (barely 1 minute). Shape into ball. Cut a large X on top with a serrated knife. Bake for 45-55 minutes. Cool before cutting.

But in most cases, itâ€™s not the starter at all.

The real mistake is underdeveloped dough.
Strong dough is what helps your bread rise tall and hold its shape in the oven.

Hereâ€™s what actually helps:
âœ” Do several sets of stretch and folds during bulk fermentation

When your dough has structure and strength, your sourdough bread will bake up light, airy, and beautifully golden.

When I first started baking sourdough bread, I remember cutting into my loaf and thinkingâ€¦

â€œWhereâ€™s the crunch?â€

It looked fine but the crust was soft, pale, and honestly, a little disappointing.

Hereâ€™s what I eventually learned: that perfect, crackly sourdough crust doesnâ€™t come from fancy gear. It comes from getting three simple things right.

1. Add steam.
Steam helps your sourdough rise before the crust hardens. I use the double pan method or pour water into a hot tray to create steam. It completely changed my bread.

2. Donâ€™t underbake.
Once the lidâ€™s off, lower the oven to 400Â°F and bake until the crust turns a deep golden brownâ€”about 20 to 25 minutes. It should smell rich and toasty.

3. Cool it uncovered.
Always cool your sourdough on a rack. If it sits on a pan or is covered, the trapped steam will soften the crust. Let it rest for at least an hour. Itâ€™s worth it.

If your sourdough crust has been soft or pale, try these three tips. They took my bread from flat and chewy to golden and crisp.

Has your crust ever given you trouble? Iâ€™d love to hear whatâ€™s worked for you.

If youâ€™ve ever felt like you canâ€™t make sourdough bread, this oneâ€™s for you. 

You donâ€™t need fancy tools or expert skills , just a little time and patience. 

This is my classic sourdough artisan bread recipe, made simple for beginners.

Classic Sourdough Artisan Bread
500 g all-purpose unbleached flour
320 g room temperature water
120 g active sourdough starter
10 g salt

Mix starter and water, then add flour and salt. Rest for 1 hour. Stretch and fold 4 times, every 30 minutes. Let it rise until doubled, shape into a round loaf, and refrigerate overnight. Bake at 475Â°F (245Â°C) in a preheated Dutch oven 
20 minutes covered, 20â€“25 uncovered.

Thatâ€™s it ! soft inside, crisp outside, and full of flavor.

Most beginners think sourdough is complicated.
It isnâ€™t when you follow a clear process & keep practicing ğŸ‘ŒğŸ¼

Here are my 5 steps that never fail, no matter how new you are to baking sourdough bread, you can do this!

âœ… 1. Use an active starter
Make sure your sourdough starter is bubbly and doubled before you mix.
Pro Tip: Feed it the night before if your kitchen is cool. Itâ€™s ready when it smells sweet and slightly tangy.

âœ… 2. Rest your dough after mixing
Mix starter, flour, water, and salt until no dry bits remain. Let it rest 45 minutes.
Pro Tip: This rest makes the dough stronger and easier to stretch later, which helps it rise higher in the oven.

âœ… 3. Stretch and fold three times
Every 30 minutes, lift and fold the dough.
Pro Tip: This replaces kneading. Youâ€™ll feel it tighten each round, which means gluten is forming.

âœ… 4. Chill overnight for better flavor
Shape your dough, cover it, and refrigerate overnight.
Pro Tip: Cold proofing builds a deeper flavor and makes the dough easier to score in the morning.

âœ… 5. Bake cold and hot
Bake the dough straight from the fridge in a 475Â°F (245Â°C) preheated Dutch oven.
Pro Tip: The cold dough hits the hot pot and traps steam, which helps your sourdough spring and open beautifully.

Two pro tips that helped me:
	
1.	Chill your dough in the fridge overnight : cold dough is easier to score cleanly.
	
2.	Use a sharp lame or razor blade and commit to your cut. Donâ€™t hesitate!

Scoring isnâ€™t just about looks

Seasons change, and so do we ğŸ‚âœ¨

Iâ€™ve been keeping a little secret. I have accepted a position at my local city hall and will be going back to work full time with people who value family and a work life balance as much as I do. And as much as I love pouring energy into this space, my familyâ€™s well being and my own mental health need to come first. This will look like fewer posts from my page and less engagement due to not being home full time anymore. But donâ€™t worry, Iâ€™m not going anywhere. The friendships I have gained in this space mean the world to me and I thoroughly enjoy being here, with you all.

With all of that said, this doesnâ€™t mean the bread dream is ending. Actually, far from it. ğŸ¥–ğŸ’› Iâ€™m still passionate about sourdough, about the art of slowing down, and about serving this community. It just means Iâ€™ll be showing up a little differently. Less often online, more focused in person, and more intentional with the loaves I bring to your table.

Starting the week of October 23rd, my bake day will officially shift to Sundays. This will give me more balance in my week, while still keeping fresh loaves in your hands for the days that matter most ğŸ¤

Iâ€™m not going anywhere. This bakery and this community are a part of who I am, and Iâ€™m so thankful for each of you who continue to support me through every season of life. Thank you for cheering me on, for understanding these shifts, and for letting me do what I love in a way thatâ€™s sustainable for me and my family.

Hereâ€™s to new rhythms, slower Sundays, and bread that always brings us together. ğŸ¥‚ğŸ

A slower, much needed month ğŸ¤

posts.caption:
Recipe below for this olive oil sourdough ğŸ’¥ #ad Adding a high-quality extra virgin olive oil, like @californiaoliveranch, makes for an incredibly supple, luxurious doughâ€”and an even better final loaf. Flavor! Texture! More flavor! I love eating this style of sourdough bread plain, but itâ€™s also incredible when sliced thick, toasted, drizzled with @CaliforniaOliveRanchâ€™s Reserve Millerâ€™s Blend Extra Virgin Olive Oil to really go all out with a robust drizzle, and finished with a flaky sea salt. Try it and tell me otherwise ğŸ™‚

Keep in mind this is a very highly hydrated dough, so hold back Water 2 and add it in very slowly at the end of mixing, once the dough has been strengthened (bassinage technique).

Makes four loaves, halve it all for two.

 

Levain:

138g type 85 flour (or can mix 35% whole wheat and 65% white flour)

138g water

69g ripe sourdough starter

 

Main Dough:

1104g medium protein white flour suitable for bread
598g type 85 flour (high extraction), or you can use 35% whole wheat, 65% white flour)
92g @californiaoliveranch 100% California Extra Virgin Olive Oil
33g fine sea salt
1151g water 1
276g water 2 (use to adjust dough consistency)
345g ripe sourdough levain

Method:
1. Mix Levain ingredients and keep warm for 5 hr
2. An hour before the levain is ripe, add the flour and water 1 to a mixing bowl and mix until no dry bits. Let rest for 1 hour.
3. Add levain, mix on speed 1 for 3 minutes, rest 10 minutes, then add salt and Water 2 as needed. Mix until smooth, 4 min on speed 2. Add the OO at the end while mixing. 
4. Bulk ferment for 3.5 hours (itâ€™s been cooler here, so longer as needed). Three sets of stretches and folds at 30-min intervals.
5. Shape and proof in the refrigerator overnight.
7. Preheat oven to 450Â°F (230Â°C), bake 20 minutes with steam, then 35 min without.

ğŸ NEW open crumb sourdough guide posted at The Perfect Loaf (link in profile and below)! All my techniques for getting a light and airy loaf of bread with an open interior. As I say in the guide, flavor is #1, of course, but having a light texture isnâ€™t all about looks, either. When the crumb is evenly (and appropriately!) open, it makes for a fantastic loaf.

How open do you like your loaves? 

For me, itâ€™s all about evennessâ€”I want the holes on the moderate side, slightly irregular and evenly distributed across the entire loaf. That signals to me the loaf has great flour, proper hydration, dough strength, vigorous fermentation (it begins with your sourdough starter!), and just the right level of proof.

3. Add levain, mix on speed 1 for 3 minutes, rest 10 minutes, then add salt and Water 2 as needed. Mix until smooth, 4 min on speed 2.
4. Bulk ferment for 3.5 hours (itâ€™s been cooler here, so longer as needed). Three sets of stretches and folds at 30-min intervals.
5. Shape and proof in the refrigerator overnight.
7. Preheat oven to 450Â°F (230Â°C), bake 20 minutes with steam, then 35 min without.

RECIPE: Sourdough Focaccia with Brined Potatoes!\xa0ğŸ™‚\xa0#ad This is the way to bring in FALL. For this focaccia Iâ€™m using the good stuff: @californiaoliveranch 100% California Extra Virgin Olive Oil, not only in the dough, but also on top, and again after baking. For the potatoes, I like to slice them to 1/16 inch on a mandolin (or flex those knife skills) and then into a brine for at least a few hours to maximize their flavor. Before topping the focaccia, drain them and dry with paper towels, and kind of tuck them into the dough in spots (see the Reel) so they get crispy.
\xa0
Sourdough focaccia recipe with brined potatoes and herbs. Makes two 10â€ focaccia.

Potato brine:
1 or 2 Yukon gold (or any yellow) potatoes, sliced into 1/16â€ slices
1 liter of water
1 teaspoon fine sea salt
\xa0
Dough:
520g medium protein white flour (â€œall-purposeâ€ flour)
385g high-protein white flour (â€œBreadâ€ flour)
19g @calfironiaoliveranch Extra Virgin Olive Oil
17g fine sea salt
588g Water 1
96g Water 2
173g ripe sourdough starter, liquid
\xa0
Method
1. Slice the potatoes, place in brine and then fridge for a few hours.
2. Mix: Add the flour, water 1, and levain to a stand mixer, mix for 5min until smooth. Let rest 10min.
3. Add salt, a splash of Water 2, and mix for another 5 minutes until the dough comes together around hook. Stream in more water if the dough can handle it. Then, stream in the olive oil slowly and mix until smooth.
4. Transfer to a bulk fermentation container for 3 hours. Do three sets of stretches and folds at 30-min intervals.
5. Grease two 10â€ round pans with olive oil (or one large 13x18 cake pan). Divide the dough into pans and cover. Let proof for 3 to 4 hours at room temperature.
7. Drain potatoes and dry (see caption). Preheat oven to 450Â°F (230Â°C). Pour about 1 tablespoon of olive oil on top of the dough and dimple aggressively with wet fingers. Spread the brined and dried potoes on top, any fresh herbs (I like thyme or rosemary), and flaky sea salt.
8. Bake for 35min. Remove to a rack to cool for a min, remove from pan and let cool completely. Drizzle on more olive oil.
\xa0

This high-hydration sourdough bread recipe is the first thing I make when I come home from travel. Intensely flavorful, open and light, and just the perfect balance between chewy, crispy, and tender.

Sourdough bread recipe (makes four 900g loaves, but divide all the ingredients in half to make just two):

Levain
138g high extraction type 85 flour
138g water
69g ripe sourdough starter

Main Dough
1013g whole wheat flour (Octane)
322g type 85 flour
368g medium protein white flour (Central Milling ABC Plus)
33g fine salt
1150g water 1
368g water 2
345g levain

[[Method]]
1. Mix Levain ingredients and keep warm for 5 hr
2. One hour before your levain is ready, add the flour and water 1 to a mixing bowl and mix until no dry bits. Let rest for 1 hour, covered.
3. Add levain, mix speed 1 for 3 minutes (or by hand for 5), rest 10 minutes, then add salt and Water 2 as needed (bassinage). Mix until smooth, 3-4 min on speed 2 in a mixer.
4. Bulk ferment for 3 hours. Three sets of stretches and folds at 30-min intervals.
5. Shape into a large batard or boule and place in a proofing basket dusted with white flour.
6. Proof in the refrigerator overnight.
7. Preheat oven to 450Â°F (230Â°C), bake 20 minutes with steam, then 40-50 minutes without. Internal temp should reach 204Â°F (95Â°C). Let cool completely before slicing.

3 years ago, but it feels like yesterday. Wish I had more pictures with you before you were gone. Wish you got to meet my son. But Iâ€™ll tell him all the stories, and Iâ€™ll always honor your memory on this day.

My parents came to this very city from Honduras in the 80s. I was born in The Bronx. We are a hard working immigrant family. I donâ€™t take for granted for one second the work my parents had to put in to this system to ensure that I became educated, learned English, and found the opportunity to thrive. But that didnâ€™t come without my own drive, dedication, and endless work ethic. Being a first generation immigrant is no walk in the park. Growing up in Louisiana with black skin is not easy either. But the best part about living in the U.S. is that our dreams are here for the taking. The success stories can be built and they can be made if you just NEVER GIVE UP.  My mom got her accounting degree at 45, raising 4 kids, cleaning houses and going to school at night. Iâ€™ll never forget those nights. 

Tomorrow is the publication day of Pan y Dulce and Iâ€™m hoping you have already pre ordered your copy. This book has been an emotional journey for me. Researching and reading about our peoples history is not always easy. While there are close to 150 recipes in this book, I have also done  my best to preserve some of our history and offer my perspective and opinion and stories regarding these beautiful and seemingly endless baking traditions. 

Look at me now fam. PAN Y DULCE is on the @amazonbooks billboard in NYC baby! PRE ORDER YOUR COPY RIGHT NOW AND LETS MAKE THESE DREAMS COME TRUEâ¤ï¸

A quick story about a girl who was always rushing to and from and trying to do it all. 
Everyoneâ€™s chasing speedâ€¦ but have you ever slowed down and let a long ferment do the work for you? This is completely true from my perspective because as someone who found bulk fermenting in bigger batches so intimidating, I never thought Iâ€™d get to a point where I actually could be proud of myself for getting there. Just getting there was what I wanted so bad. So I took that as my goal and made it a mission to conquer that fear, as hard as it was because I didnâ€™t want to fail. 
I stayed true and focused on learning my dough - letting my dough tell me the story and not rushing the process. 
We put so much pressure on ourselves to master everything at onceâ€¦ but the truth?
Most of the growth happens when you focus on one small skill and repeat it until it feels natural.
For me, it was bulk rise. 
One day at a time. One batch at a time. 
No rushing. No comparing. Just learning with my hands and watching the dough teach me.
If youâ€™re in that season too-where youâ€™re trying to get â€œbetter at it allâ€- let this be your reminder:
Start with one thing. Practice it. Trust it.
Your progress will show up long before perfection ever does.

Here are 3 things that helped me the most when I first started out baking sourdough. 
ğŸ«¶ğŸ»#1 ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Start simple, stay consistent.
Stick to ONE recipe ONE method
(â€œMaster the basics before changing anythingâ€). I found a recipe that worked for me just by watching others and using their recipes as guidance and over time it began to improve, I tweaked what I felt confident enough to do for me. When youâ€™re just beginning it gets overwhelming-you donâ€™t need 20 formulas- just one that you can practice until it feels natural.
ğŸ«¶ğŸ»#2 ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» A visual cheat sheet for dough readiness. I practiced this over and over so many times till I felt confident enough to know my dough. I started to look for the signs - all of them:
	â€¢	Smooth top/dome shape
	â€¢	Puffy sides/and pulls nicely away from your bowl when u touch it 
	â€¢	Jiggly bowl
	â€¢	Light bubbles
Once you practice this step it does become alot easier to know when u are done bulk fermenting, patience is key here & trusting the process too. 
ğŸ«¶ğŸ»#3 ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» Donâ€™t compare your loaf to someone elseâ€™s year 3. Give yourself room to learn. Your loaf will tell its own story. Everyoneâ€™s dough behaves differentlyâ€¦ and everyoneâ€™s journey starts in a different place.
What youâ€™re seeing online is often someoneâ€™s year 3, 4, or 5 not their first few tries. Your job right now isnâ€™t to match their results - itâ€™s to learn your dough, build confidence, and enjoy the process.
 I hope this helps you at your stage of your journey - save this for future success and drop any comments belowğŸ¥°ğŸ«¶ğŸ»ğŸ¥–âœ¨ğŸğŸŒ¾â™¥ï¸#sourdoughbaking #sourdoughbaker #sourdoughbread #sourdoughfromscratch #sourdoughbreads #sourdoughloaves #sourdoughjourney #bakingwithsourdough #bakingsourdoughathome #coquitlambaker #bakingwithconfidence #slowandsteady #practicemakesperfect #comparisonisthethiefofjoy

Iâ€™ve also been doing a three-rise process: one bunk fermentation, one post shaping and pressing into the pan, and then one more after adding toppings. The third rise makes for a fluffier crumb. Folks ask me pretty frequently how I bake at home. I guess it is kind of interesting: Iâ€™ve been baking sourdough for over a decade, but I donâ€™t really have much gear. Iâ€™ve never used a stand mixer for bread, because I like hand-mixing. I have a scale, a stone, a turkey roaster lid for steam, a lame, a few bannetons, and a few sheet pans. Oh, and a Sourdough Home, which was a wonderful birthday gift! I donâ€™t think it takes much gear to make great bread. The practice is much more important. \n\nIâ€™ve been playing around with using my three loaf pans to bake tiny focaccias from one big dough. I find that about 100-150 grams of dough is just right for a loaf pan focaccia. I could see baking eight of these at once. These have a whole range of toppings, from pesto potatoes to cream cheese cubes to tiny heirloom tomatoes. I didnâ€™t fully keep trackâ€¦but thatâ€™s how I like it. ğŸ™‚

As promised in my previous post, I want to share a few tips for creating breadscape gardens like these, followed by the formula I used for this dough. First, the tips:

1) As I mentioned previously, the best base Iâ€™ve ever found for the surface of the dough is a thin layer of simple basil pesto. The flavor is wonderful and complements the vegetables, and it also helps them stick to the surface of the dough. 
2) Donâ€™t just lay the vegetables on top of the dough. Nestle them in there. Play around with pushing some of them in at different depthsâ€”this adds interest to the loaves once baked!
3) Spray your loaves with a light layer of vegetable or olive oil before baking. This is magical, because it prevents burning, minimizes shriveling, AND seems to help maintain the vibrancy of the color. This combined with the pesto on the surface of the dough envelopes the vegetables with a protective layer, and makes the bread more delicious too.

The veggies I used are detailed in the previous post. On to the formula. (I canâ€™t promise Iâ€™ll use exactly the same formula next time, because I rarely do the same thing twice, but I can promise this one works!)

400g all-purpose flour
50g spelt flour (if youâ€™ve got in on handâ€”if not, then use what youâ€™ve got!)
250g water
100g 100% hydration sourdough starter
30g melted butter
20g olive oil
50g honey
10g salt

Mix it all together. Let it sit for an hour or so. Give it a few folds. Let it sit more! Fold again. Do that about four times over the course of 3-4 hours. Then let it rise between 50 and 100%. 

I allow loaves to proof for about 90 minutes before topping and baking, which I do at 425f. 

Happy baking, peace nâ€™ power to you, more to come.

Itâ€™s been a while since Iâ€™ve created a gardenscape, so this one felt real soothing and meditative. ğŸ™‚

This base has olive oil, a touch of honey, and a bit of rye. Toppings included basil pesto, red onion, scallions, carrots, cherry tomatoes, bell pepper, peas, poppy seeds, sesame seeds, dried garlic, and Swiss Alps seasoning. 

I have a few tips for creating these loaves! The first is to use a very thin layer of pesto as a base. It doesnâ€™t interfere with the color, it adds moisture and flavor, and it helps the vegetables stick to the surface of the dough. Iâ€™ll share a few more tips with the post-bake photos. If folks are interested in more specific dough specs, I can also post those. Peace nâ€™ power to all.

Baking soda! 

Baking soda works for sourdough discard recipes because sourdough contains the acids needed to create a reaction. Some notes:
â€¢A more acidic starter means a stronger reaction, but usually the flour in an acidic starter is more broken down leading to a less-fluffy, but more tender, result.
â€¢Too much baking soda will leave a metallic taste ğŸ¤¢
â€¢Baking soda and baking powder are *almost* the same. Baking powder contains the acids needed for the reaction, while baking soda doesnâ€™t. If thereâ€™s enough acid in your discard, you donâ€™t need baking powder. 1 tsp soda = 1 tbsp powder

Not all discard recipes use baking soda to add fluff. This is just one method out of several.

I love to make flourless discard recipes for those who love (or need) a fully-fermented dish. While this isnâ€™t possible for every recipe, I do have several recipes on my blog that donâ€™t include added flour. Featured in this video are:

â€¢McGriddle Sheet Pan
â€¢Mediterranean Skillet
All flourless, all on my blog. 

You can find all my sourdough discard recipes on my blog, or comment â€œDISCARDâ€ (caps not necessary; IG only; FB check the comments) for the link to your DMs â™¥ï¸

Anyone else a 50/50 whole grain baker? 

I love whole grains for their flavor and nutrients, but I love to bake 50/50 with them (50% whole grains, 50% white flour) for balance. This ratio gives me lots of whole grain flavor while still being able to produce an airy loaf.

When working with whole grains, there are some things youâ€™ll want to consider! Your loaf will:
-Absorb more water
-Struggle to retain air
-Be slightly more sour (depending on how, exactly, fermentation rolls)
-Ferment faster
I talk about each of these in depth on my blog post.

This loaf is whole grain spelt and wheat + 50% white flour. You can find the recipe on my blog, or comment â€œGRAINâ€ for the link to your DMs (FB check the comments)

My sourdough version of socca âœ¨

This recipe is SO easy and SO versatile. Make it gluten-free by using a gluten-free starter. To serve:

â€¢Drizzle it with olive oil and sprinkle with your favorite seasoning (I like salt + herbs like oregano or rosemary).
â€¢Make it a pizza crust. Top with your favorite toppings, cook, and enjoy!
â€¢Serve it alongside your favorite dip, like hummus or chutney.
â€¢Top it with mashed avocado and a fried egg. Yum!
â€¢Layer on chopped, fresh greens or thinly-sliced fresh or roasted veggies.

Recipe below, or comment â€œSOCCAâ€ (Instagram only, caps not necessary, FB check the comments) for the link to my blog post with more info. 

This is a discard recipe, but the chickpeas have to hydrate, hence the minimum 30 minute rest. Iâ€™ve tested up to four hours at room temp, or you can stick it in the fridge for 12-24 hours before baking! The only difference is a longer rest lends a more fluffy interior. 

Recipe:
â€¢1/2 cup (65 g) chickpea flour
â€¢1/2 cup (120 g) sourdough discard
â€¢1/2 cup (120 g) water
â€¢1 1/2 tbsp (18 g) olive oil, plus more for the skillet
â€¢1/2 tsp (3 g) salt

Blend, rest, preheat oven to 475 F with 10-inch cast iron skillet inside. Use a 12-inch skillet for thinner socca (and reduce baking time). When the skillet is hot, drizzle generously with olive oil, pour in the batter, and bake directly under the broiler for 12-14 minutes. For slightly better browning on top, you can broil for the last 2-4 minutes, but this is optional. Serve warm with another drizzle of olive oil, sprinkle of salt, and your favorite herbs. Or check above for other serving options.

Cramique Recipe (Sweet Belgian Brioche):
Ingredients:
â€¢ 250g bread flour
â€¢ 150g whole milk (50g warm + 100g room temp)
â€¢ 50g sweet stiff starter
â€¢ 50g sugar (rubbed w/ lemon zest & vanilla)
â€¢ 5g salt
â€¢ 1 whole egg + 1 yolk
â€¢ 50g softened butter
â€¢ 75g pearl sugar

Instructions:
1ï¸âƒ£ Mix & Hydrate: Combine room-temp milk, eggs, sugar (pre-rubbed with zest & vanilla), and flour in a stand mixer. Mix into a shaggy dough. Let rest 15-20 min to hydrate.

2ï¸âƒ£ Develop the Dough: Add the sweet stiff starter, knead for a few minutes. Dissolve salt in warm milk, add to dough, and knead until incorporated.

3ï¸âƒ£ Butter Enrichment: Slowly incorporate softened butter, kneading until smooth, elastic, and slightly sticky.

4ï¸âƒ£ Bulk Ferment: Cover and let the dough rise at room temp for 2-4 hours, or overnight in the fridge for deeper flavor.

5ï¸âƒ£ Shaping & Proofing: Gently fold in pearl sugar, shape into a loaf or rolls, and place in a greased pan. Let proof 1-2 hours until puffy.

6ï¸âƒ£ Bake: Brush with egg wash, sprinkle extra pearl sugar, and bake at 375Â°F (190Â°C) for 20-30 min until deep golden brown.

âœ¨ Soft, buttery, and a little indulgentâ€”just like us.
